title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: There is no interview as such. One needs to apply to the Graduate School with GRE and TOEFL/IELTS scores. The admission depends upon the academic background, relevant skills and prior research experience. Luck play a role here as well. The professor should have a vacancy in his/her group and availability of funds is crucial!
Interview Questions: I am not working in that area anymore, would you still like to work with me?

title: Staff Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: I emailed my resume to the manager, who responded with an email requesting a phone interview. That went well (lasted about 30 minutes), so I was given a chance to come in for a face to face. I met with three people, then was tested on basic office software usage and writing ability.
Interview Questions: Describe a mistake you made and how you went about fixing it.

title: Analyst, IT Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Mar 2010
Interview Descriptions: Difficult and you must network in order to get your foot in the door.
Interview Questions: Explain how you would handle a difficult manager

title: Training Education Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Jan 2010
Interview Descriptions: Applied online but sent email and resume directly to hiring manager.  Had to use my network to find out who the hiring manager was.  Duke HR does not give that information up easily.  Had phone interview with department manager, group interview with operations manager and two people in similar positions to the one I was interviewing for, and a 1:1 interview with the executive director.  Had to submit a written response to a job-related exercise.
Interview Questions: Create 3-5 metrics an organization could use to measure its progress toward implementing a new clinical intervention.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Dec 2009
Interview Descriptions:
The interviews went great. Yet rather a long process if you are trying to get a job soon.

Know your stuff, be prepared, be able to argue three of for general themes in your resume that really connect to the position.
Interview Questions: What skills and experiences do you bring to the position?

title: Duke Engage Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Nov 2009
Interview Descriptions: The Duke Engage process required us to submit an application online and after that we had to interview with the site coordinator who asked a series of questions about personality, goals for the future and what we wanted to get out of the program
Interview Questions: Why this program instead of the other 20 you could apply to

title: Research Technician II Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Sept 2009
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was straightforward, much the same, if not a tad less competitive than for similar positions at Ivy League schools (I interviewed and obtained a job at Yale as well). If you're sharp, and present yourself well, you'll get in. You have to be teachable for this job. Communicate that, somehow. If you lack experience, don't try to schmooze your way around that. There are plenty of labs around campus that can give you the experience you need. Don't make up anything/stretch things, and you'll do well. You'll be in there working with very bright/capable graduate students and post-docs. Look  the part, act the part.
Interview Questions: What is your greatest strength? How will your skills allow you to contribute directly to this research? And what are your goals for the future?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Sept 2009
Interview Descriptions: I emailed the PI I was interested in working for directly; he wrote back and we met at a conference. We spoke on the phone afterward to ensure that there was mutual interest, and then he flew me out so I could meet the lab members and present my graduate work.
Interview Questions: What are your career goals?

title: Personal Trainer Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Aug 2009
Interview Descriptions:
Phone Interview Covered your background and experience, reference checks, and behavioral questions.

i.e. "Tell me about a time where you had to step up into a leadership role, and provide actions to support your answer"

or "Tell me a time where you had to solve a problem and what were your actions?"
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to initiate leadership and what was the end result?

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: interview was professional and cordial. Interviewed with three different faculty members and several graduate students. Duke paid for a nice meal as part of my visit.
Interview Questions: How will your research translate into your teaching?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Feb 2009
Interview Descriptions: The initial phone interview took approximately 45 minutes, where we talked about research and potential projects to work on.  My advisor invited me to visit Duke for a look around campus and to have interviews.  I had about 7 one-on-one interviews with other faculty that lasted about 30 minutes each.  I then met with my potential advisor for a couple of hours and mainly talked about research.  The interviews were pretty informal, with mostly scientific talk, little personality questions.
Interview Questions: What research are you interested in conducting?

title: Statistician II Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Nov 2008
Interview Descriptions: the process as smooth....pone interview the met the manager and the team. They are amazing group
Interview Questions: why do you think you are fit for the job.

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Aug 2008
Interview Descriptions: presentation and meetings with group members
Interview Questions: what is your vision?

title: Postdoctoral Associate Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Mar 2008
Interview Descriptions: I sent a email to a professor who has a similar background with mine. Then he called me after two days. No research topics mainly about the onsite interview arrangement. And  one is how long does it take for me to graduate.  During the onsite interview, we had a dinner together, then the next day I gave a presentation. You need to know your topic well. You will always have lots of questions.
Interview Questions: all the question are  not general questions. you need to understand your research very well.

title: Academic Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Duke University (Durham, NC) in Jan 2008
Interview Descriptions:
Make sure your resume gets thru their giant HR system.  If you can get an email to the hiring person directly, do so.  

Interview was fine and normal.  Had to sell myself to a few of the professors.
Interview Questions: Typing a writing sample from a professor's handwritten notes that were barely legible and on a topic completely unfamiliar to me.
